node.title: Plane stress for finite strain in tensor mechanics module
node.bodyText:
Dear all,
I try to apply plane stress condition for finite strain problem in the Tensor mechanics module but didn't get success. Below is part of the code I used to specify it.
[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  out_of_plane_strain = strain_zz
[]

[Modules]
  [TensorMechanics/Master/mech]
    strain = FINITE
    add_variables = true
    new_system = true
    incremental = true
    formulation = TOTAL
    planar_formulation = WEAK_PLANE_STRESS
    save_in = 'resid_x resid_y'
  []
[]

[Variables]
  [strain_zz]
  []
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [resid_x]
  []
  [resid_y]
  []
  [nl_strain_zz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]

[AuxKernels]
 [strain_zz]
   type = RankTwoAux
   rank_two_tensor = total_strain
   variable = nl_strain_zz
   index_i = 2
   index_j = 2
  []
[]

The error message is: attempted to set unregistered parameter(s) for WeakPlaneStress object:  large_kinematics, stabilize_strain
Any idea to fix it?
Thanks.
QTT

Hello
I dont think the new lagrangian formulation is supported with any plane formulation.
I ll fix the error message, you are not hitting the right one
Guillaume
so to fix it, set new_system = false
We have the capability now, but I haven't ported it into the action/physics yet... Create an issue and assign me plz.
on it.

node.title: Temperature (and time) dependence for materials
node.bodyText:
Hi there, just getting used to using moose and I want to have material properties that change depending on the temperature. I have tried a few different things, like using parsed functions to feed into parsedmaterials or the built in function capabilities for something like thermal conductivity.
There must be a simplier way to do this, I have provided the current state of my material block which runs but doesnt converge....
Any help is appreciated! (I have had to change the functions and names of blocks etc, however the structure is the same as I use)
[Materials]
[fluid_cp_dT_parsed]
type = ParsedMaterial
block = 'fluid'
    expression = '(1 / ( temperature^(2) ))'
    property_name = specific_heat_dT
    coupled_variables = 'temperature'
[]

[fluid_cp_parsed]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    block = 'fluid'

    expression = '1'
    property_name = specific_heat
    coupled_variables = 'temperature'
[]

[fluid_thrm_cond_dT_parsed]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    block = 'fluid'

    expression = '(1 / ( temperature^(2) ))'
    property_name = thermal_conductivity_dT
    coupled_variables = 'temperature'
[]

[fluid_thrm_cond_parsed]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    block = 'fluid'
    expression = '1'
    property_name = thermal_conductivity
    coupled_variables = 'temperature'
[]

[fluid_density_parsed]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    block = 'fluid'
    expression = '(1 / ( temperature^(2) ))'
    property_name = density
    coupled_variables = 'temperature'
[]

[]

@Jake-HW-Miles I would normally implement time dependence of a material property
by passing a function of time to the material object, see for instance this one where we implement
a time depend coefficient for creep:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/src/materials/CrystalPlasticityDislocationUpdate.C
"creep_ao_function" is the relevant one. You can see an example input file of our recent paper on creep:
https://github.com/ngrilli/c_pfor_am/blob/main/test/tests/Paper_CP_PFF/polycrystal_right_elastoplastic_variableGc.i
see the function "creep_rate_prefactor".
Temperature dependence is in the same material object above.
You can see we have made the crystal plasticity laws temperature dependent
by couping "temperature".
Best Regards,
Nicolò

Hello
First you should make sure it converges with constants everywhere. Then introduce dependencies on nonlinear variables one at a time.
If you can use AD (for example with the ADParsedMaterial) you should try to do that. It will make sure the derivatives of the quantities with regards to the nonlinear variables are well captured
Guillaume

node.title: Cannot run examples from the "Kraken/problems" directory for the "Kraken" MOOSE-application?

I followed the installation instructions outlined here (link: https://github.com/Z-Laboratory/Kraken/blob/main/README.md); however, I was unable to run problems from the "Kraken/problems" directory. ./kraken-opt -i ../problems/Dragonskin_20_test_1D_final.i

There are several warnings stating that 'this code is deprecated' - does this mean I need to downgrade my installed MOOSE version to an older version?
Kind regards,
Kurt.

Hello
Deprecation messages mean you should update your input, not use an older moose. Deprecated code is not broken, but it won't work anymore one day.
There is an object in that input that is not known to the application you are running. You should contact the developers of kraken to know where it came from
Guillaume

node.title: failed restart or recover from a checkpoint on HPC cluster
node.bodyText:
Hello there,
I have done a crystal plasticity simulation with contact mechanics and my simulation was killed due to time limit. Now when I want to restart or recover, I get segmentation fault. It looks like that the restart is loaded. I am using --n-threads=32 and replicated mesh.
Could you please help me to figure this out?
Ali

Hello
DId you output one or two checkpoint files? Can you try the older one? If the simulation is killed while the file is being written, it will be corrupted.
Does it load fine without threads?
Guillaume
This is a known issue #26485, specific to the crystal plasticity part of the tensor_mechanics module. Updates are not there in the main code yet.
It s ok to keep the post open. It s best to subscribe to the relevant issue notifications to stay informed about the topic btw

@schakrabortygithub I have reinstalled MOOSE following the merged resolved issue. Now I can see that the recovery option works but my time increments quickly goes to a very small time increment. my time increment was stable at dt = 0.0004 before previous job termination but now it goes to  dt = 3.8147e-10 after 10 steps. Is this an expected behavior? Probably I'll hit "dt min reached" error!

@xajezade I do not know the input script of your crystal plasticity simulation. Is it possible to share the minimal input script that will reproduce the problem.
Otherwise, can you can first try with some simple CP problem by using the script located at modules/solid_mechanics/test/tests/crystal_plasticity/stress_update_material_based/bicrystal_test.i and then restart the simulation. Plot the time vs pk2 from both the simulations in one graph. You should get something similar to this:

The time step reducing means the solve is failing.
See the troubleshooting failed solves instructions to get it to converge

@schakrabortygithub I am going to test this! I am simulating indentation problem, so I have also contact in addition to crystal plasticity. I'll try to make a simpler model to see if I can reproduce the same issue for further investigation.
@GiudGiud I have an interrupted simulation due to the time limit that I have on our HPC system. Before the simulation was killed, I had a stable time increment and a converged solution. I have outputted the last two checkpoints, I get the same problem if I restart from both. Doesn't it suggest that the restart procedure caused this failing?

If you can reproduce this failing on even an early checkpoint, a time step which would have passed if you did not use checkpoints, then yes it points to a failure in checkpoints
Which moose commit are you using now? It should say in the header of the log

Here is my screenshot of the simulation log on the time increments before restart:

and here is just after restart:

Again my simulation is still running but with a very small time increment:

It looks like that the restart cannot restore contact properly and want to reestablish contact. Note that I don't have a problem without contact. I am going to test the example on 2d indenter to see if I can reproduce the same issue.
Here is the Framework information:
Framework Information:
MOOSE Version:           git commit bfbeaaf on 2024-04-04
LibMesh Version:         7dbd90ade88cb16a5e855a4c345454c9c146ebec
PETSc Version:           3.20.3
SLEPc Version:           3.20.1

On a separate note, modules/contact/examples/2d_indenter/ example cannot be restarted using --recover option. Also, I have outputted checkpoints. I tried to read from mesh.cpr file from input file but it gives me this error:Cannot use appendMeshGenerator() because there is not a generator to append to!

node.title: Compute Isotropic Elastic Tensor
node.bodyText:
Hello Team,
I am trying to work with temperature and concentration dependent isotropic elastic tensor. I was able to compute isotropic elastic tensor dependent on temperature using 'ComputeVariableIsotropicElasticityTensor' using temperature as 'args'. However, i want the isotropic elastic constants (tensor) which depends on both temperature and concentration.
Do any one have any idea??
Help will be highly appreciated.
Thank you,
Bashant Bist

Hello
Unless you can find another elasticity tensor material that does what you want, you will have to create a new material.
The variableIsotropic..Tensor is a good example to start from
Guillaume

node.title: Convergence when using ScalarLagrangeMultiplier
node.bodyText:
I am working to code up a Poisson-Nernst-Planck model by Bazant et al.:
\begin{aligned}
\nabla c_{+} + c_{+} \nabla \phi &= 4j \\
\nabla c_{-} - c_{-} \nabla \phi &= 0 \\
-\epsilon^2 \Delta \phi &= \frac{1}{2}\left(c_{+} -c_{-}\right) \notag
\end{aligned}
subject to the boundary conditions
\begin{aligned*}
\phi(0) &= 0 \\
\phi(1) &= 1 \\
c_{+}(0) &= 1.09 \\
c_{+}(1) &= 0.91
\end{aligned*}
and the constraint 
$$
\int_{\Omega} c_{-} dx = 1.
$$
In the paper, the authors integrated two second order differential equations to obtain the first order differential equations (1) and (2) using a boundary condition for $c_{-}$. I have substituted some values directly into the model that appears in the paper to simplify the presentation.
I have successfully been able to run a MOOSE input file which solves for the system of PDEs with the boundary conditions but without the constraint.
I am now working to implement the constraint using ScalarLagrangeMultiplier. It seems like a straightforward application of the available kernel.
However, as soon as I introduce this constraint into the input file, the solver struggles to converge.
I started with just coding $c_{-}$ with the constraint (letting all the other variables be 0 essentially) and that was able to converge. I was able to add in $\phi$ with just its diffusion term (so working with the simplified PDE $-\epsilon^2 \Delta \phi = 0$), but as soon as I add in the CoupledForce term for phi  (so working with the simplified PDE $-\epsilon^2 \Delta \phi = -0.5 c_{-}$), the solver is unable to converge.
Looking through documentation, it was mentioned somewhere that adding in constraints does make solving more difficult.
Do you have any recommendations for what type of Executioner and/or Preconditioning would help convergence?
This is what I currently have, which works for just the diffusion term but not the CoupledForce term in the residual equation for $\phi$.
[Preconditioning]
  # Preconditioning is required for Newton's method.
  [./coupled]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'LINEAR'
  l_max_its = 30
  l_tol = 1e-6
  nl_max_its = 300
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-4
  #line_search = none
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -ksp_gmres_restart -sub_ksp_type
                         -sub_pc_type -pc_asm_overlap'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu      31                  preonly
                         lu          1'
[]
I was working with the LU in the petsc_options_value because when I first introduced the diffusion term (so did not just set $\phi$ to be 0), I was having a zero factor pivot error, and that solution was proposed in another discussion post.
I believe it was before I added in $\phi$ I was having a line_search error issue and saw in another discussion post that sometimes the default does not work for convergence, so I had input the line_search = none to rectify that, but then I believe when I added in $\phi$, while I had to add in the LU, I was able to get rid of that command without convergence failing.
I'm trying to recreate the results of the paper so I won't really know if the solution I am getting is correct until everything is incorporated. Even though I have convergence for this simple case, I don't know that it is to the correct solution, but I want to have convergence in the more complicated case so that I can verify that it is correct.
I appreciate any suggestions you may offer.

Hello
Have you tried to add a nonzero factor shift? Often constraints DoFs introduce a 0 on the diagonal
What kind of convergence error are you getting? The linear or nonlinear solve?
Guillaume
This helped a lot, thank you! My code is now running (although not yet producing there correct results). It was linear solve convergence.

node.title: SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator & SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
node.bodyText:
All,
In order to study "SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator" and "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" to be used for an InterfaceKernels app such as "InterfaceDiffusion," I ran the model shown below and produced the same results. So, I would like to say both "SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator" and "SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator" can be used for InterfaceKernels apps.
Please confirm.  S. Thomas
[Mesh]
[gen]
type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
dim = 2
nx = 20
ny = 20
xmax = 1
ymax = 1
[]
[./subdomain1]
input = gen
type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
bottom_left = '0.5 0 0'
top_right = '1.0 1.0 0'
block_id = 1
[../]
[./interface]
type = SideSetsAroundSubdomainGenerator
input = subdomain1
block = 0
normal = '1 0 0' # right
new_boundary = 'interface'
[../]
.
.
[InterfaceKernels]
[./Interface]
type = InterfaceDiffusion
variable = 'u'
neighbor_var = 'v'
D = 1
D_neighbor = 3
boundary = 'interface'
[../]
[]
or
[./interface]
input = subdomain1
type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
primary_block = '0'
paired_block = '1'
new_boundary = 'master0_interface'
[../]
.
.
[InterfaceKernels]
[./Interface]
type = InterfaceDiffusion
variable = 'u'
neighbor_var = 'v'
D = 1
D_neighbor = 3
boundary = 'master0_interface'
[../]
[]

Hello
Yes they should both be able to produce valid sidesets that you can use downstream.
The parameters are a little different they differ a bit in how they specify the sideset
Guillaume
Thank you, Guillaume, as always.

node.title: Posting guidelines
node.bodyText:
Before posting, please review the following set of guidelines
Your question is likely to have already been answered

please search the documentation website (especially the troubleshooting page)
please search the github discussions forum, using the error output by moose as keywords for example. If you find the solution there, great! If not, then create your own discussion thread. Do not post on an old already answered discussion thread! These are not monitored as closely as new threads. You can however add a link to the seemingly related thread in your newly created post.

We need enough information to help you!

for build or runtime issues, tell us about your platform, your operating system, your compiler (all of which can be obtained with executing moose/scripts/diagnostics.sh in the console)
for unexpected results, add a figure if relevant
for convergence issues, consider uploading your input file and your mesh.
Input files may be shared directly in the post (formatted with triple back quotes ``` please), but the most convenient way to share input files, meshes (and possibly your application) is to share a link to a public github repository. Please avoid uploading .zip files
for a seg fault or an MPI_Abort crash, follow the instructions here first, and give us a full backtrace from a debug mode build

Style guidelines

we strongly suggest that posts be made in English so that they are directly accessible to the entire community
no screenshots of text. These are not searchable by the next user who runs into the same issue
use the back quotes (3 for multiline pastes: ```) to format input files, code AND output logs. These are unreadable otherwise

Update moose AND its dependencies (libmesh, petsc)

We would rather always be supporting you on an up-to-date version of MOOSE, because old bugs have been fixed
Updating libmesh (through a conda update for example) while not updating moose or the other way around can cause hard to understand errors, most often at compile time
After updating, there can be left over compiled objects / libraries. If getting some compilation errors after updating, it is worth cleaning the MOOSE repository (make clobberall is most often plenty sufficient, but for some external packages, like pcre, you will need to commit all your developments then run git clean -xfd to remove them). If build errors are happening for an app, you may need to run git submodule foreach git clean -xfd to clear out all old compiled objects from every dependency (including MOOSE)

If after a week no one has answered, please tag a MOOSE developer

node.title: Common Installation Issues
node.bodyText:
If MOOSE does not build, before asking for help on this forum:

update MOOSE with

git fetch origin
git commit -am "Saving my current work"
git rebase origin/devel


update the moose dependencies.
If you used conda to install moose, this is simply conda update moose-dev
Try to build again with make -j6 in moose/test

If this fails, try this next step:

clean the repository after having saved all your work with git add / git commit
using

cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -Xfd

then try to make again
If the above fails, run the diagnostic script and attempt to address any failure/warning messages:
cd ~/projects/moose
scripts/diagnostics.sh
In the event you continue to run into issues and wish to post a question, please include the above diagnostic output.
ImportantBefore posting, please review the Posting guidelines

node.title: Simulating excavation and refill of full blocks using CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
node.bodyText:
Hi all,
For various tasks in the field of engineering and mining, the excavation (and possibly refilling) of defined volumes must be modelled. Examples are excavation pits or the excavation of a tunnel. The discussions here at https://github.com/idaholab/moose/discussions contain several corresponding questions and hints (e.g. #23677, #20601, #16387, #25264, and others), on how this can be achieved with Moose.
To the best of my current knowledge, there are three options for modelling the removal of model parts in Moose:

Option 1: The element is not really removed from the model, but a reduced stiffness and weight is assigned. An example model that uses this approach can be found here: coal_mining
Option 2: A restart analysis is performed. Strictly speaking, a series of Moose models is calculated in which the subsequent model has an adapted mesh and imports the initial state from the predecessor model. As this approach "breaks down" the model definition into individual models, I have not pursued this approach any further to date.
Option 3: Elements are moved from an "active" subdomain to an "inactive" subdomain during a Moose calculation. I would like to pursue this option with this "show and tell".

First of all: Many thanks to @GiudGiud, @Kavan-Khaledi, and @AdrienWehrle for their valuable advices, without which this show and tell would not have been possible.
Screenshot: excavated block at t=0.4

The code below creates a rectangular volume ("Box1") in the centre of which a small cube ("Box2") is to be removed at t=0.4. To keep the model simple, both Box1 and Box2 are linearly elastic. The approach can be described very briefly as follows:

In addition to the subdomains Box1 and Box2, in which the corresponding elements are located, an empty subdomain 3 is created.
Subdomain 3 contains a greatly reduced "physics" so that the elements moved there are "inactive".
The tensor mechanics master block is therefore only created for the subdomains of Box1 and Box2. Gravity also only works here.
In subdomain 3, a diffusion kernel is only created as a "dummy" kernel.
When Box2 is moved to subdomain 3 is controlled by a function (PiecewiseConstant). The value of this function is stored in an aux variable. This aux variable is in turn used by a CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier to move the elements of Box2 to subdomain 3 at t=0.4.

In the model initially Box1 and Box2 are active. At t=0.4 Box2 gets "removed". As expected, as a result of the unloading, the material of Box1 lifts in the proximity of the removed Box2.
To run the input file, your Moose app needs the modules "MISC" (for the gravity) and "TENSOR_MECHANICS".
As a side-note: I presume that in productive models (especially with more complex material behaviour) a mixture of option 1 (reduction of stiffness and weight) and option 3 (subdomain modifier) is probably the method of choice. First make it soft and light and then move it to the inactive subdomain.
Code Block: Moose Input File

# testing construction stages
# primary model units (m | s | kg --> N/m²)

#some model-specific variables
material_density = 21.5E3         # kg/m^3
gravitational_acceleration = 9.81 # m/s^2
sig_top = 0.0                     # N/m^2
z_top = 10.0

[Problem]
  kernel_coverage_check = false
  material_coverage_check = false
[]

Box2_inactive = '3'
inactive_domain_blocks = ${Box2_inactive}

[Mesh]

  [BaseMesh]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    elem_type = "TET10"
    dim = 3
    nx = 20
    ny = 20
    nz = 2
    xmin = -10
    xmax = +10
    ymin = -10
    ymax = +10
    zmin = -2
    zmax = +2
  []

  [Box1]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = "BaseMesh"
    block_id = 1
    location = "INSIDE"
    bottom_left = "-20 -20 -2"
    top_right   = "+20 +20 +2"
  []

  [Box2]
    type = SubdomainBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = "Box1"
    block_id = 2
    location = "INSIDE"
    bottom_left = "-2 -2 +2"
    top_right   = "+2 +2 0"
  []

  add_subdomain_ids = ${inactive_domain_blocks}

[]

active_domain_blocks =  '1 2' #Box1 Box2

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  large_kinematics = false
[]

# ===== Tensor mechanics for all active domain blocks =====
[Modules/TensorMechanics/Master]
  [./all]
    new_system = true
    formulation = total
    strain = small

    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
    add_variables = true

    generate_output = 'stress_xx stress_xy stress_xz stress_yy stress_yz stress_zz '
  []
[]

# ===== Gravity =====
[Kernels]
  [./Gravity]
    type = Gravity
    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
    use_displaced_mesh = false
    variable = disp_z
    value = -${gravitational_acceleration}
  []
 [./donothing1]
    type = MatDiffusion
    block = ${inactive_domain_blocks}
    variable = disp_z
    diffusivity = 1e-7
  []
 [./donothing2]
    type = MatDiffusion
    block = ${inactive_domain_blocks}
    variable = disp_x
    diffusivity = 1e-7
  []
 [./donothing3]
    type = MatDiffusion
    block = ${inactive_domain_blocks}
    variable = disp_y
    diffusivity = 1e-7
  []
[]

# ===== Boundary Conditions: Fixies at XMin, XMax, YMin, YMax, ZMin =====
[BCs]
  
  [./BoundaryXMin_DispX]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'left'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []

  [./BoundaryXMax_DispX]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'right'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []
  
  [./BoundaryYMin_DispY]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'bottom'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []
  
  [./BoundaryYMax_DispY]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'top'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []
  
  [./BoundaryZMin_DispX]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'back'
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
  []

  [./BoundaryZMin_DispY]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'back'
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
  []

  [./BoundaryZMin_DispZ]
    type = DirichletBC
    boundary = 'back'
    variable = disp_z
    value = 0
  []

[]

# ===== Initial Conditions: Initial Stress Field =====
[Functions]
  [ini_xx]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '(-sig_top - rho * g * (z_top - z)) * K0'
    symbol_names  = 'sig_top     z_top      rho                   g                               K0  '
    symbol_values = '${sig_top}  ${z_top}   ${material_density}   ${gravitational_acceleration}   0.3 '
  []
  [ini_yy]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '-sig_top - rho * g * (z_top - z)'
    symbol_names  = 'sig_top     z_top      rho                   g                               K0  '
    symbol_values = '${sig_top}  ${z_top}   ${material_density}   ${gravitational_acceleration}   0.3 '
  []
  [ini_zz]
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '(-sig_top - rho * g * (z_top - z)) * K0'
    symbol_names  = 'sig_top     z_top      rho                   g                               K0  '
    symbol_values = '${sig_top}  ${z_top}   ${material_density}   ${gravitational_acceleration}   0.3 '
  []
[]

# ===== Materials (linear-elastic to keep it simple) =====
[Materials]

  [./volAll_elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
    youngs_modulus = 450E6 # 450 MN/m^2
    poissons_ratio = 0.15
  []

  [./volAll_stress]
    type = ComputeLagrangianWrappedStress
    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
  []

  [./volAll_stress_base]
    type = ComputeLinearElasticStress
    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
  []

  [./volAll_ini_stress]
    type = ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress
    eigenstrain_name = ini_stress
    initial_stress = 'ini_xx 0 0  0 ini_yy 0  0 0 ini_zz'
    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
  []

  [./density]
    type = GenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = density
    prop_values = ${material_density}
    block = ${active_domain_blocks}
  []

[]

# ===== Block Activation/Deactivation =====
[Functions]
  # this function at which time (x-value) the block is active (y=1) or inactive (y=0)
  [Box2_ActivationStateFunction]
    type = PiecewiseConstant
    direction = left
    xy_data = '0.0  0
               0.2  0
               0.4  1
               1.0  1'
  []
[]
# aux variable to store the value of Box2_ActivationStateFunction
[AuxVariables]
  [Box2_Activation_AuxVariable]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
  []
[]
# link Box2_ActivationStateFunction and Box2_Activation_AuxVariable
[AuxKernels]
  [Box2_Activation_FunctionAux]
    type = FunctionAux
    variable = 'Box2_Activation_AuxVariable'
    function = 'Box2_ActivationStateFunction'
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]
# move Box2 between subdomains
[UserObjects]
  [Box2_SubdomainModifier]
    type = CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier
    coupled_var = 'Box2_Activation_AuxVariable'
    criterion_type = ABOVE
    threshold = 0.5
    block = 2 #'Box2'
    subdomain_id = 2 #Box2
    complement_subdomain_id = ${Box2_inactive}
    execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
  []
[]

# ===== Executioner =====
[Executioner]
  type = Transient

  end_time = 1.0
  [TimeSteppers]
    [BlockEventTimeStepper]
      type = TimeSequenceStepper
      time_sequence = '0.0 0.2 0.4 1.0'
    []
  []
  
  solve_type = 'PJFNK'
  petsc_options = '-snes_converged_reason'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
  petsc_options_value = ' lu       mumps'

  nl_abs_tol = 1E-3
  nl_max_its = 400
  
  l_tol = 1E-3
  l_max_its = 200
[]

[Outputs]
  perf_graph = true
  exodus = true
[]
Hello, I would like to ask how to realize the filling process? Thank you for your help.

Hello @PEI0214, the CoupledVarThresholdElementSubdomainModifier can move elements from one subdomain to another. The example above moves elements from a subdomain "with physics" to a subdomain "without physics". To model a filling process, elements can be moved from a subdomain "without physics" to a subdomain "with physics" using the same technique.

When simulating the fill process, a non-convergence occurs when moving elements from a subdomain “without physics” to a subdomain “with physics”. Is this due to mesh distortion? Do you have any good solutions?

When moving elements from one subdomain to another, you may very well want to ramp in or ramp out various material parameters over time. Which parameters these are depends very much on what you want to model. In solid mechanics, however, density is often one such parameter. As a rule of thumb: try to model sufficiently well what happens in reality (e.g. a water dam is usually not put down "all at once" - rather in many small steps).
Do you have examples of simulated fill construction? If so, can you provide it for learning?Thank you.
How do you implement the "Option 2"?

Do you have examples of simulated fill construction? If so, can you provide it for learning?

Currently I have no example showing this.

How do you implement the "Option 2"?

Option 1 and 2 are not shown in this example.
